Tucson knew that Talon was right.  He nods and decides its best to follow h=
er advice.

" Of course, we know nothing about this enemy and to charge him=
 blindly and head on, would be a costly mistake.  I can't afford to make mi=
stakes that would endanger the life on this planet."

Local artist who spec=
ializes in illustration, using traditional and digital media.

cialize in hand made crafts.  Great for any occasion!

alk.

>

r baby's or babies' life

> --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Sandra Panico=
 <magicquartz@...> wrote:
> >
> > Tucson looks to the paintings thoughtfull=
y. 
> > 
> > " Yes, I believe you're right Talon. These depictions tell all=
. And if this so called other deity is a physical being, then it must be ev=
il, or else it wouldn't be painted in black. And if it is a physical being,=
 it must be stopped. And I have a feeling that perhaps its best if I face t=
his being personally. Now, let's see... This pictograph gives a location.. =
Ah, I got it, these paintings resemble a path that I happen to know rather =
well. And some of this writing.. I think it means " Blight" . Tucson to bas=
e, over. I have identified an enemy, via pictograph images found on my loca=
tion. The name of our new enemy is Blight, and by the look of the pictograp=
hs, he is a Predacon. I will proceed to locate Blight now . Or at least get=
 him to heed my warning. Tucson out."
> > 
> > He narrows his eyes, leaps u=
p onto a large boulder and gives off his thunderous roar, hoping that Bligh=
t gets the message.

> > > Talon:
=
> > >

nk that you are actually a sort of deity as well as the other one?"
> > > 
=
> > > --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Sandra Panico <magicquartz@> wrote:
> =
> > >
> > > > Tucson embraces Talon with his tail around her shoulders.
> >=
 > > 
> > > > " So will I. Talon, so will I. But that doesn't mean we can't=
 try to recreate a little portion of life on our own planet. This seed we w=
ere given, it needs soil, water, light and something to plant it in. Perhap=
s we can find a place where there is an abundance of soil and take that wit=
h us. "
> > > > 
> > > > Just as he spoke, a Protohuman, carrying an offeri=
ng of fish, kneels down before Tucson and Talon. Tucson looks to the offeri=
ng. It was a most generous portion of fish. Yet now he could not eat it, bu=
t he knew Talon would need nourishment. He nods gently to the Protohuman an=
d accepts his offering with a gentile touch of his nose on the man's should=
er. He allows him to stroke his snout as some sort of good luck ritual.  Th=
e man bows in graciousness to Tucson's gesture of kindness and leaves him b=
e with Talon.
> > > > 
> > > > " I'm not so sure what all of that meant but=
, whatever it was, it was a very kind gesture on his part. I wonder if thes=
e people had any interaction with the old Silver Dragon.. " 
> > > > 
> > >=
 > It isn't long before others come to offer more gifts to him and Talon. O=
ne of the Protohumans points to a painting on a rock, with white portraying=
 silver, in a primitive image of a large reptile with outstretched wings.
>=
 > > > 
> > > > " Oh, I see now.. Yes, they have seen him before. To them h=
e is a guardian, and the more offerings they gave him, he would return thei=
r kind gestures by offering his protection. But there is more to these pain=
tings.. A strange mysterious figure, with an aura around it.. To me it seem=
s evil. Another idol, someone else to worship. .. People portrayed in black=
 and white.. White, meaning those who look to the Silver Dragon and black t=
o those who worship the intimidating idol.. I've seen ancient pictographs b=
efore on Cybertron, and these are different but in the same format. Talon i=
f the dragon is a physical being, then this dark idol must be as well. We n=
eed to find it, before it lays harm to anyone."

st who specializes in illustration, using traditional and digital media.

> > > > > --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, S=
andra Panico <magicquartz@> wrote:
> > > > > >
> > > > > > With a gentile s=
mile, Tucson returns the kiss and holds his wing over them to provide a mom=
ent alone with Talon. After the kiss he lowers his wing and notices that a =
collection of small creatures surrounding him and Talon . Yet they do so in=
 a fashion of admiration rather than hostility. Tucson looks to them curiou=
sly.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > " I'm not sure why these creatures are curiou=
s about us but it appears as if they're here to admire rather than attack. =
I wonder... "
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > He stands up and gets back into beas=
t mode, and sits down once more. The creatures draw closer to him and sit b=
eside him and Talon. It was clear that the Silver Dragon was a source of co=
mfort to these creatures, but that was about to change once he and Talon le=
ft for Cybertron. It was a massive guilt slammed upon his heart. Yet how co=
uld he get the animals to understand that he had to leave them in such a sh=
ort time? He was now their guardian and they were looking up to him for pro=
tection. 
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > " Talon, these creatures remember the ol=
d dragon that sought to their protection and realize that I have taken his =
place. It's as I thought, they aren't aware of who we really are, and where=
 we are from. They will not understand that we must leave them shortly, for=
 good, and Primus knows what will happen to them once we leave. ... Talon, =
I hear something coming. It's not a Predacon but it's a fairly large creatu=
re."
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > Not far from them, Tucson spots the scales of=
 a rather large reptile, that appears to be fishing in the stream next to t=
hem. He watches attentively and at that moment, the creature lifts its head=
. It was another dragon. Yet this one was a bit smaller than he was, but th=
e same coloration. He takes note of its slender shape. It was female. She l=
ooks to him as he looks to her. She slowly approaches him and they look gen=
tly to each other like brother and sister. In draconic vocalization, Tucson=
 explains who he is and his dilemma. She intern rumbles back and bows her h=
ead. She nods as he does. It was their way of communicating as Tucson looks=
 back to Talon.
> > > > > > 
> > > > > > " Apparently the old dragon has fa=
mily here. They are scattered but they exist. And she said that she will pr=
otect these creatures and this land along with her brethren for as long as =
they live. And she wishes us good luck on our journey."
> > > > > > 
> > > =
> > > With that, the dragoness leaves them peacefully to enjoy their time t=
ogether. With a gentile groan, the creatures too, depart. It was truly a sp=
iritual moment for both of them.

 > > > > --- In nbwrpg@yahoogroups.com, Sandra Panico <magicquartz@> wrote:=

> > > > > > > >
> > > > > > > > Tucson holds Talon gently with an arm arou=
nd her shoulders. He looks up and then back to her.
> > > > > > > > 
> > > =
> > > > > " Like a branch on a tree that has broken off during a storm and =
regrows in a different direction than it had been, before it had broken off=
. I know exactly how you feel. I feel the same way. At one time, I was blin=
d, rolled on four wheels and I always seemed to be an Autobot rebel. I foug=
ht along side with my comrades but I wasn't good at following orders. I was=
 well grounded but lost at the same time. Then, I met you and things began =
to change on a more positive note. You may not believe this, but you helped=
 me to find my path, and you saw me on the right road and guided me to my t=
rue fate. Soon afterwards, I became a Prime, acquired seventeen more wheels=
, and almost looked like Optimus Prime, yet different. But one thing didn't=
 change, I was still battling blindness off and on. Then, a third change, d=
ue to extensive damage to my previous form, which could not be repaired, I =
was guided to my final evolution, this one. All of these things wouldn't ha=
ve come about if I had never met you. And I wouldn't have it any other way.=
 Talon, I will miss this planet as much as you are, and hopefully we can te=
ll our offspring all about this planet and it's wondrous varieties of life =
that live here."
> > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > The rodent climbs down an=
d drops a nut into his hand, and chatters to him.
> > > > > > > > 
> > > > =
> > > > " This is for us to keep? Thank you, we will take good care of it."=

> > > > > > > > 
> > > > > > > > He places the nut in Talon's hand.
> > > =
> > > > > 
> > > > > > > > " I think we have a way to bring back a small re=
minder of this planet. Let's see if we can encourage it to grow on ours."

 a moment alone with Talon. After the kiss he lowers his wing and notices t=
hat a collection of small creatures surrounding him and Talon . Yet they do=
 so in a fashion of admiration rather than hostility. Tucson looks to them =
curiously.<br>
> > > > > <br>
> > > > > " I'm=
 not sure why these creatures are curious about us but it appears as if the=
y're here to admire rather than attack. I wonder... "<br>
> > > &g=
t; > <br>
> > > > > He stands up and gets back into beast=
 mode, and sits down once more. The creatures draw closer to him and sit be=
side him and Talon. It was clear that the Silver Dragon was a source of com=
fort to these creatures, but that was about to change once he and Talon lef=
t for Cybertron. It was a massive guilt slammed upon his heart. Yet how cou=
ld he get the animals to understand that he had to leave them in such a sho=
rt time? He was now their guardian and they were looking up to him for prot=
ection. <br>
> > > > > <br>
> > > > > " Talon=
, these creatures remember the old dragon that sought to their protection a=
nd realize that I have taken his place. It's as I thought, they aren't awar=
e of who we really are, and where we are from. They will not understand tha=
t we must leave them shortly, for good, and Primus knows what will happen t=
o them once we leave. ... Talon, I hear something coming. It's not a Predac=
on but it's a fairly large creature."<br>
> > > > > <br>
&gt=
; > > > > Not far from them, Tucson spots the scales of a rathe=
r large reptile, that appears to be fishing in the stream next to them. He =
watches attentively and at that moment, the creature lifts its head. It was=
 another dragon. Yet this one was a bit smaller than he was, but the same c=
oloration. He takes note of its slender shape. It was female. She looks to =
him as he looks to her. She slowly approaches him and they look gently to e=
ach other like brother and sister. In draconic vocalization, Tucson explain=
s who he is and his dilemma. She intern rumbles back and bows her head. She=
 nods as he does. It was their way of communicating as Tucson looks back to=
 Talon.<br>
> > > > > <br>
> > > > > " Appare=
ntly the old dragon has family here. They are scattered but they exist. And=
 she said that she will protect these creatures and this land along with he=
r brethren for as long as they live. And she wishes us good luck on our jou=
rney."<br>
> > > > > <br>
> > > > > With that=
, the dragoness leaves them peacefully to enjoy their time together. With a=
 gentile groan, the creatures too, depart. It was truly a spiritual moment =
for both of them.<br>
> > > > > <br>

> > > > > > ><br>
> > > > > > &gt=
; Tucson holds Talon gently with an arm around her shoulders. He looks up a=
nd then back to her.<br>
> > > > > > > <br>
> > =
> > > > > " Like a branch on a tree that has broken off duri=
ng a storm and regrows in a different direction than it had been, before it=
 had broken off. I know exactly how you feel. I feel the same way. At one t=
ime, I was blind, rolled on four wheels and I always seemed to be an Autobo=
t rebel. I fought along side with my comrades but I wasn't good at followin=
g orders. I was well grounded but lost at the same time. Then, I met you an=
d things began to change on a more positive note. You may not believe this,=
 but you helped me to find my path, and you saw me on the right road and gu=
ided me to my true fate. Soon afterwards, I became a Prime, acquired sevent=
een more wheels, and almost looked like Optimus Prime, yet different. But o=
ne thing didn't change, I was still battling blindness off and on. Then, a =
third change, due to extensive damage to my previous form, which could not =
be repaired, I was guided to my final evolution, this one. All of these thi=
ngs wouldn't have come about if I had never met you. And I wouldn't have it=
 any other way. Talon, I will miss this planet as much as you are, and hope=
fully we can tell our offspring all about this planet and it's wondrous var=
ieties of life that live here."<br>
> > > > > > > <br>=

, we will take good care of it."<br>
